newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai T-bill repo rates, spots end mixed.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai T-bill repo rates, spots end mixed.

text.p: Contracts on the treasury bill repurchase market in Shanghai closed mixed on Thursday.
Three early-maturing contracts ended down with the market losing support from the domestic A share markets, which had performed poorly in the past few days, traders said.
But three late-maturing contracts rose due to an expected reduction of fund supply on the market in the mid-term after Beijing banned state banks trading on the market last week.
The annual rate for the most actively traded seven-day contract fell to 8.00 percent from 10.06 percent on Wednesday.
Total turnover of the six-contract market rose to 3.2 million lots from 1.4 million lots.
One lot is 1,000 yuan face value of treasury bills.
Traders said the sluggish A share markets made short-term money demand decrease, depressing the early-maturing contracts.
"But the interest rates for late-maturing contracts rose with investors expected money supply in the mid-term to drop because of the ban on state banks," one trader said.
Traders said they expected the repo rates to go down slightly on Friday.
Contracts on the T-bill spot market in Shanghai ended mixed in sluggish trading on Thursday on a lack of market-moving news, traders said.
The most actively traded 10-year bond that matures in June 2006 fell to 121.90 yuan from 122.62 yuan.
The bond will be suspended from trading on Friday for the payment of the first year's interest.
Combined volume of the eight-contract market rose to 1.6 million lots from 1.2 million lots.
Traders said they expected the contracts to move narrowly on Friday due to the suspension of the 10-year bond, the market leader.
